body:
yes, that's correct, thanks!!

Do you have an explanation why this was not caught by the current tests? We do `test_get_params`, naively I would think it should fix this?

I incorporated the fix in this refactor here:
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3708

issue.title: [ENH] default `get_params`/`set_params` for `_HeterogenousMetaEstimator` & [BUG] fix infinite loop in `get_params` for `FeatureUnion`, with hoesler

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Restructuring without changing its external behavior. Neither fixing a bug nor adding a feature.

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR adds a default `get_params`/`set_params` for the `_HeterogenousMetaEstimator` with varying part based on a private attribute, which can replace many of the copy/pasted `get_params`/`set_params` for concrete heterogeneous estimators.

This replaces abstract methods of the same name that raise an error if called.

For this to work as a replacement of copy-pasted methods in descendants, two changes are made:

* `_HeterogenousMetaEstimator` no longer inherits from `BaseEstimator`, so is turned back into a mixin from a base class
* descendants now must inherit from `_HeterogenousMetaEstimator` *before* a base class

A full refactor is carried out to replace duplicated `get_params`/`set_params` with the default from `_HeterogenousMetaEstimator`.

No deprecation is necessary since the class is private, and the public interfaces do not change.

Testing is via the main test suite's existing tests for the params interface points.

Also includes a bugfix to #3789, as pointed out by @hoesler, with the attribute accessed in `FeatureUnion` changed from `transformer_list` to `_transformer_list`.

The bugfix is certified by the test in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3792.

body: Would be important to understand why this was not detected to have a general test case (and avoid breaking this again).

issue.title: [ENH] second test case for `FeatureUnion`, construction without names

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR adds a second test case for `FeatureUnion`, estimator list passed without names.

This should surface the bug reported in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/3789 on current `main`, and it should pass when this is run on the fix in https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3708.

body:
It might be because none of the test cases covered invocation without names, which is the same as the dunder result?

Added a test case here, which should fail if this is the case:
https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/3792

Thanks for the fast response. I think you're right, that the non-tuple args are causing this.

But the root cause might be something different:

The execution got stuck [here](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/0ce1b838bd9837b7f80f8e6ddce2fa912059b881/sktime/base/_meta.py#L46).

PyCharm doc on the dict.update method says (can't find it in the official docs):
> D.update([E, ]**F) -> None. Update D from dict/iterable E and F. If E is present and has a .keys() method, then does: for k in E: D[k] = E[k] If E is present and lacks a .keys() method, then does: for k, v in E: D[k] = v In either case, this is followed by: for k in F: D[k] = F[k]

This it is calling the `__getitem__` method of the transformer (because D[k] = E[k]) and this creates a new new pipeline with `return ColumnSelect(key) * self` and `__mul__` calls itself infinitly with `self_as_pipeline * other`.

ahhhhh, makes sense. Thanks, this explains it!

The added test )only estimators case) should cover this failure, and it seems it indeed does.

Great. FYI: I debugged a bit deeper because realized I didn't fully understand what's going on here and how to prevent the loop, even with unexpected arguments.

Now I got it. In the `out.update(estimators)` statement, what happens is indeed the ` for k in E: D[k] = E[k]` case. In python, this translates to `{k: estimator[k] for estimator in estimators for k in estimator}`.

But what is `for k in estimator`? The answer is here: https://docs.python.org/3/library/functions.html#iter
> .... or it must support the sequence protocol (the __getitem__() method with integer arguments starting at 0)

Since estimator has the `__getitem__` method, you can `iter()` it, which throws the infinite sequence at it 0,1,2,3,..... without ever returning `null`, which would stop the iteration.

So, I guess the lesson here is, be careful by implementing the `__getitem__` method, isn't it? Because all of a sudden, you support iteration by the sequence protocol.

> So, I guess the lesson here is, be careful by implementing the __getitem__ method, isn't it? Because all of a sudden, you support iteration by the sequence protocol.

Hm - how do we avoid this? Is there a smart way to throw an exception?

Perhaps in the constructor of `ColumnSubset`?

I guess, the best would be to exclude int as key type of `__getitem__(self, key)`, if we misuse that method for something different from getting elements of a sequence. If that is not possible, I don't see anything we can do to avoid unexpected iteration, as with the `dict.update` methods. So, the best we can do is testing.

I think `int` needs to be possible, since `int` can be a column index type in subsetting...

> So, the best we can do is testing.

Yes, the new test case catches the error. I'd say coverage was just too low in this case.
